) Subsection
is revised to update the address for the Department of State’s, Office of Affairs for Passport Services. (
) Subsection
is revised and subsection
is added to indicate that special agents will obtain a Buccal DNA cheek swab when processing arrested persons before they can be processed by the U.S. Marshals. (
) Subsection

is revised to clarify that in addition to the documents in the group files, a of the Enforcement Action Review Form must be maintained in the Special Agent in Charge’s administrative files; pursuant to procedures implemented by the Director, Operations memorandum dated March
, [Subject: Uniform Policy for Enforcement Action File Maintenance].

Subsection 9.4.12.15.1 is revised to clarify that in addition to the documents in the group files, a of the Enforcement Action Review Form must be maintained in the Special Agent in Charge’s administrative files; pursuant to procedures implemented by the Director, Operations memorandum dated March 7, 2005, [Subject: Uniform Policy for Enforcement Action File Maintenance].
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM supersedes IRM 9.4.12 dated August 11, 2008, as well as Director, Operations memorandum dated March 7, 2005, [Subject: Uniform Policy for Enforcement Action File Maintenance]; and Director Warrants; Forfeiture memorandum dated March 17, 2010 [Subject: Obtaining A Buccal DNA Cheek Swab from Arrestees].

) This section provides guidance to special agents as to what to do before, during, and after making an arrest. The section also provides information regarding domestic fugitives, wanted persons, and international fugitives. following will be discussed in this section: (cid:

) During most investigations, it will be advantageous to wait until after filing mation or receiving an indictment to make an arrest. The time limit under Speedy Trial Act starts to run at the time of an arrest. Arrests should be only in situations where the investigation would be in jeopardy if an arrest not made or when an arrest warrant has been issued. (

) Special agents will not normally make warrantless arrests except under circumstances, such as a physical attack on an employee or forcible seized property in the presence of the special agent (see subsections and
). An arrest warrant lessens the likelihood of a complaint of arrest being filed against the arresting special agents. (

) Special agents may request and execute an arrest warrant. The special will be responsible for recommending to the Special Agent in Charge (SAC) the merits of Criminal Investigation (CI) requesting the issuance and of an arrest warrant. Upon the concurrence of the SAC, the special agent forward the request to the attorney for the government. In approving the SAC will consider the strict time provisions of the Speedy Trial Act. In circumstances, CI will execute an arrest warrant only upon the request of attorney for the government. (
) Special agents have statutory authority to make arrests with or without a warrant. (
) The statutory authority for special agents to make arrests is contained in
USC §

, as amended. This statute enables special agents to: to a. execute and serve search warrants and arrest warrants, and serve subpoenas and summonses issued under authority of the United b. make arrests without warrant for any offense against the United States relating to the Internal Revenue laws committed in their presence, or

Special agents will not normally make warrantless arrests except under circumstances, such as a physical attack on an employee or forcible rescue of seized property in the presence of the special agent (see subsections and 9.4.12.7). An arrest warrant lessens the likelihood of a complaint of false arrest being filed against the arresting special agents.
statutory authority for special agents to make arrests is contained in 26 §7608, as amended. This statute enables special agents to:

execute and serve search warrants and arrest warrants, and serve subpoenas and summonses issued under authority of the United States make arrests without warrant for any offense against the United States relating to the Internal Revenue laws committed in their presence, or for

a. execute and serve search warrants and arrest warrants, and serve subpoenas and summonses issued under authority of the United States b. make arrests without warrant for any offense against the United States relating to the Internal Revenue laws committed in their presence, or for

Investigative any felony cognizable under such laws if they have reasonable believe that the person to be arrested has committed or is such felony c. make seizures of property subject to forfeiture under the Internal laws (

) An arrest without a warrant is a serious matter and could subject the agent(s) to civil liability. Therefore, in order for a special agent to make a Warrants rantless arrest, a felony must have been committed in the agent’s the agent must reasonably believe the person arrested committed a (see subsection

) If the special agent intends to make a warrantless arrest in a tax that still requires Department of Justice (DOJ) approval, the SAC should pre-referral advice from DOJ to prevent making an arrest in an that may not be authorized for prosecution. All other investigations, such money laundering arrests, are approved directly by the attorney for the ment after being referred by the SAC. (
) The decision to seek arrest warrants is the responsibility of the attorney government. However, DOJ authorization for tax violations is required. (
) The Supreme Court has stated that, in the absence of a statute limiting Federal agents’ power to arrest without a warrant, those agents have the Authority powers of arrest as a private citizen. (
) A special agent’s power to make a warrantless arrest as a private citizen, when valid under state law, is not invalid because the crime is outside the scope of the Internal Revenue laws. (
) Special agents should use extreme caution in acting as a private citizen should be familiar with the arrest laws of the locality where the arrest (
) In some states, special agents are granted peace officer status (see IRM Authority). (
) Arrest means to take custody of a person accused of a crime for the of holding or detaining him/her to answer a criminal charge. Arrest (

) Three basic elements must be present before an arrest is complete: a. The agents must have the authority to make the arrest. an Arrest b. The offender must know that an arrest is intended. c. The offender must submit to the authority of the agents. (

) When making an arrest, special agents should: a. announce their official identity to the person being arrested b. display their issued badges and credentials when circumstances c. make known to the offender that they are being arrested d. inform the offender of the reason for such action e. take control of the arrestee

any felony cognizable under such laws if they have reasonable grounds to believe that the person to be arrested has committed or is committing any such felony make seizures of property subject to forfeiture under the Internal Revenue laws
The decision to seek arrest warrants is the responsibility of the attorney for government. However, DOJ authorization for tax violations is required.
Special agents should use extreme caution in acting as a private citizen and should be familiar with the arrest laws of the locality where the arrest occurs.
Arrest means to take custody of a person accused of a crime for the purpose of holding or detaining him/her to answer a criminal charge.
) After the offender submits to the authority of the arresting special agent(s), further resistance or an attempt to escape may constitute another offense. (

) While reasonable force may be employed to affect an arrest, the use of excessive force may subject the special agent to liability for tort damages. Firearms may be used only in accordance with the guidelines in IRM
, Use of Force Procedures. (
) The procedures for securing an arrest warrant are dependent upon the following factors: a. whether the investigation is a Title
violation requiring approval by the DOJ, Tax Division b. whether approval by the DOJ, Tax Division to prosecute the Title
violation has occurred or is pending c. local US Attorney policies and attorney for the government preferences regarding obtaining arrest warrants (

) In situations when arrest is appropriate, it is preferable to receive an indict- ment, prior to the issuance of an arrest warrant. This avoids many problems including the early release of the evidence during preliminary hearings. hearings inevitably result in the release of information which otherwise not have been disclosed until much later. (
) After an indictment, there is no preliminary hearing or probable cause because the grand jury has already determined probable cause (see Fed. Crim. P. R

) The issuance of bench warrants may be discouraged by attorneys for the ernment. It is widely believed that such warrants should only be used where there is a genuine flight risk or reason to believe the defendant is a danger the community. There may be other reasons justifying arrest including simultaneous searches which may counterbalance the reluctance of an attorney for the government regarding the issuance of warrants. (

) With the issuance of warrants, there is a concern that the government may appear to be overreaching. Absent a strong basis for a warrant, attorneys the government may prefer to have the defendant appear for a warrant, via issuance of a subpoena. (
) The decision to issue an arrest warrant is the responsibility of the attorney the government. (
) The SAC of the special agent making the arrest should review and approve the Arrest Checklist. See Exhibit
, Arrest Checklist, Form
, as well as the Risk Assessment Guide, Exhibit
The risk assessment guide requires the approval of the SAC prior to execution of the arrest The arrest checklist and risk assessment guide will be maintained in the tigative file (see subsection

) A special agent planning an arrest will ensure the following is addressed: a. conducting pre-operation intelligence gathering b. preparing a site survey c. reviewing staffing d. reviewing equipment needs Internal Revenue Manual

The issuance of bench warrants may be discouraged by attorneys for the gov- ernment. It is widely believed that such warrants should only be used where there is a genuine flight risk or reason to believe the defendant is a danger to the community. There may be other reasons justifying arrest including planned simultaneous searches which may counterbalance the reluctance of an attorney for the government regarding the issuance of warrants.

Investigative e. reviewing communications f. conducting a pre-operational briefing g. notifying the US Marshals Service and arranging for pre-trial detention, applicable h. contacting family services if minors will be present i. contacting animal control if animals will be left unattended after the (

) Special agents will not use force to accomplish a recovery of property in forcible rescue investigations; however, they may make an immediate (without an arrest warrant) when the forcible rescue takes place in their presence. (

) Special agents should consider all available options before making the decision to arrest. Specifically, the special agent should: a. Advise the person attempting or making the rescue that he/she is commit or is committing a crime. b. Consider the IRS’ likelihood of recovering the asset(s) being rescued currency or other readily disposable assets versus machinery, automo- biles, etc.). (
) In many instances, withdrawal from the scene and applying for an arrest warrant may be the best alternative, particularly in a volatile situation. (

) Regardless of the decision, if a forcible rescue occurs, the facts and stances should be immediately reported to the SAC. If an arrest is not the SAC will discuss the issue with Criminal Tax (CT) Counsel. If the is made to obtain an arrest warrant, the request will be made to the for the government. (

) Special agents should not become involved in emergency driving in rescue investigations. Sufficient facts will normally exist for special agents subsequently obtain an arrest warrant without endangering the lives of by engaging in emergency driving (see Directive No
- Emergency Driving IRM
, Criminal Investigation Directives). (
) In the event a physical attack is made upon an IRS employee, special may arrest the attacker using only such force as is reasonable and in accordance with the provisions outlined in IRM
, Use of Force dures. (
) Generally, special agents will not have occasion to arrest a juvenile for a violation of the Internal Revenue laws. (

USC §

many instances, withdrawal from the scene and applying for an arrest may be the best alternative, particularly in a volatile situation.
For the purpose of this provision, and as defined in
USC §
, a juvenile is a person who has not attained his
th birthday, or for the purpose of pro- ceedings and disposition for an alleged act of juvenile delinquency, a person who has not attained his
st birthday; and juvenile delinquency is the violation of a law of the United States committed by a person prior to his
th birthday which would have been a crime if committed by an adult.

If special agents are ordered or requested to serve an arrest warrant upon a juvenile, or if it is deemed necessary to arrest a juvenile without a warrant, the special agents must comply with the procedures set forth in
USC §
, Custody Prior to Appearance Before Magistrate. This section provides the following:

) If special agents are ordered or requested to serve an arrest warrant upon a juvenile, or if it is deemed necessary to arrest a juvenile without a warrant, special agents must comply with the procedures set forth in
USC §

, Custody Prior to Appearance Before Magistrate. This section provides the following: a. Whenever a juvenile is taken into custody for an alleged act of juvenile delinquency, the arresting officer shall immediately advise such juvenile his/her legal rights, in language comprehensive to a juvenile, and shall immediately notify the Attorney General and the juvenile’s parents, guardian, or custodian of such custody. b. The arresting officer shall also notify the parents, guardian, or custodian the rights of the juvenile and of the nature of the alleged offense. c. The juvenile shall be taken before a US magistrate immediately. In no event shall the juvenile be detained for longer than a reasonable period time before being brought before a US magistrate. Note: When special agents arrest a juvenile, they should notify the office of the Attorney in the judicial district in which proceedings will be held. This will satisfy the statutory requirement for notification to the Attorney General a juvenile is arrested. (
) A foreign national is defined as any person who is not a United States (
) Treaty obligations of the United States require Federal law enforcement officers to notify certain foreign authorities when foreign nationals have been arrested or detained in the United States. (
) To ensure that Americans abroad obtain the treatment to which they are entitled, it is essential that the United States not violate any of its obligations under these treaties. (

) When special agents arrest or otherwise detain a foreign national, the special agent must promptly inform the detainee of his/her right to have government informed of such event and that he/she has a right to consular access. In most cases, the foreign national has the option to decide whether have consular officials notified. Some agreements with certain countries require mandatory notification when their nationals are arrested or detained. See Exhibit

, Mandatory Notification Countries and Jurisdictions. In these instances, the foreign national has no choice regarding notification and the arresting or detaining special agent will notify the consulate or the of the situation without delay. See Exhibit
, Suggested Statements to Arrested or Detained Foreign Nationals, which provides suggested that may be used to advise foreign nationals of consular rights. (

) If the detainee requests notification, the arresting or detaining special agent must ensure that notification is immediately given to the nearest consulate or embassy of the detainee’s country. The physical addresses and numbers of the foreign consular offices in the United States can be obtained from the internet site, http:www.state.gov. (

) Foreign consular officers have the right to visit their nationals who are in prison, custody, or detention, to converse and correspond with them and to arrange for their legal representation, unless the person being held expressly opposes these actions. They must refrain from acting on behalf of a foreign Internal Revenue Manual

a. Whenever a juvenile is taken into custody for an alleged act of juvenile delinquency, the arresting officer shall immediately advise such juvenile of his/her legal rights, in language comprehensive to a juvenile, and shall immediately notify the Attorney General and the juvenile’s parents, guardian, or custodian of such custody. b. The arresting officer shall also notify the parents, guardian, or custodian of the rights of the juvenile and of the nature of the alleged offense. c. The juvenile shall be taken before a US magistrate immediately. In no event shall the juvenile be detained for longer than a reasonable period of time before being brought before a US magistrate.

Foreign consular officers have the right to visit their nationals who are in prison, custody, or detention, to converse and correspond with them and to arrange for their legal representation, unless the person being held expressly opposes these actions. They must refrain from acting on behalf of a foreign
national if the foreign national opposes their involvement. In addition, officers may not act as attorneys for their nationals. (

) Special agents should keep written records sufficient to show compliance the notification requirements. These records should show all notifications to foreign consular representatives. In addition, in cases in which notification is the discretion of the detained foreign national, these records should show the foreign national was informed of the option of consular notification, the when the foreign national was so informed, and whether or not the foreign national requested that consular officials be notified. If confirmation of receipt of notification is available, it should be saved if possible. See Exhibit Suggested Fax Sheet for Notifying Consular Officers of Arrests or for an appropriate document to record compliance with the notification ments. (
) A provisional arrest request is the process that DOJ uses to extradite a located in a foreign jurisdiction. Arrest (
) Questions regarding provisional arrest requests should be directed to CI’s INTERPOL Representative. (

) In situations where an arrest is made in a wagering occupational tax tion, the SAC will ensure that related investigations involving any wagering Made in Wagering excise tax investigations and those Title

violations delineated in IRM Criminal Statutory Provisions and Common Law, committed in contravention the Internal Revenue laws are completed promptly. All related violations can then be prosecuted concurrently, in order to comply with the strict time provi- sions of the Speedy Trial Act and to avoid dual prosecution problems. (
) After the arrested person is in custody, special agents must follow certain cessing procedures. After Arrest (

) Special agents who make an arrest are responsible for the safety and of the arrested person. Special agents may detain the arrested person for a of the Arrested reasonable time until they can conveniently and safely take him/her before a US magistrate. (

) When the circumstances prevent an immediate hearing, the arrested person may be taken to the nearest police station, US Marshals Office, or local detention center/jail. The detention facility should be approved for custody of Federal prisoners, if feasible. The arrested person will be held as a Federal prisoner at the facility until arrangements are made for his/her hearing. (
) However, the person arrested shall not be detained longer than absolutely necessary before being granted a hearing. (
) Special agents must conduct a thorough search of the arrested person. should search for weapons, contraband, means of escape, and instruments of Arrested used in the commission of the crime. (
) A reasonable attempt should be made to have a special agent of the same gender as the arrested person present to conduct the search of the body Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
X
national if the foreign national opposes their involvement. In addition, consular officers may not act as attorneys for their nationals.

) Special agents should keep written records sufficient to show compliance with the notification requirements. These records should show all notifications to foreign consular representatives. In addition, in cases in which notification is at the discretion of the detained foreign national, these records should show that the foreign national was informed of the option of consular notification, the date when the foreign national was so informed, and whether or not the foreign national requested that consular officials be notified. If confirmation of receipt of notification is available, it should be saved if possible. See Exhibit
, Suggested Fax Sheet for Notifying Consular Officers of Arrests or Detentions, for an appropriate document to record compliance with the notification require- ments.

, Criminal Statutory Provisions and Common Law, committed in contravention of the Internal Revenue laws are completed promptly. All related violations can then be prosecuted concurrently, in order to comply with the strict time provi- sions of the Speedy Trial Act and to avoid dual prosecution problems.

professionalism, common sense, and maintenance of human dignity. (

) When a subject is arrested and has a passport, the passport may be retained by the law enforcement agency for evidentiary purposes. However, when it is no longer needed for the law enforcement purpose and the person is still in custody or subject to a bond or parole, the passport must be returned to the Department of State at the following address:

Special agents will not delay an arrested person’s appearance before a Magistrate for the purpose of an extensive interview or attempting to statement. However, if the statement can be obtained without unnecessary delay and if the person arrested is willing to make a statement, it should recorded subject to the procedures and safeguards outlined in IRM
, views. IRM

is also applicable to interviews of arrested persons in custody of local authorities. Prior to questioning a person arrested by local or state authorities, special agents should determine whether the local authorities gave an adequate stitutional warning. If no warning was given by local authorities, or if their warning was a standard pre-interview warning by the special agents may not be assure the admissibility of statements made by the arrested person. In this situation, the special agents may have to take additional dispel the impression that the interviews by local authorities and by the agents are really a single, continuous period of questioning. This may be accomplished by: a. allowing a reasonable amount of time to lapse between the local law forcement interview and questioning by the special agents b. explaining to the arrested person the distinction between the special agent’s interest in the investigation and the local police’s interest c. obtaining an affirmative waiver of rights reflecting the arrested understanding of these distinctions Criminal Tax should be consulted to resolve questions concerning the adequacy of constitutional warnings given by local or state authorities and assist special agents in selecting appropriate measures to counteract any apparent deficiencies.

Special agents will not delay an arrested person’s appearance before a US Magistrate for the purpose of an extensive interview or attempting to obtain a statement. However, if the statement can be obtained without unnecessary delay and if the person arrested is willing to make a statement, it should be recorded subject to the procedures and safeguards outlined in IRM
, Inter- views.

) Two sets of fingerprint cards will be prepared for each arrested person on Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) Form FD–
, Fingerprint Card (white the card with red ink). Each field office has been provided with pre-printed print cards showing the agency’s name and the originating agency identifier (ORI) number. (
) The photographs described in subsection

, Photographing the Arrested Person, will be attached to one set of fingerprint cards; this set will retained in the investigative file. The second set of fingerprint cards will be mailed directly to the Identification Division, Federal Bureau of Investigation, Washington, DC,
) Additional pre-printed fingerprint cards showing the agency’s name and ORI number can be obtained from the FBI by completing FBI Form
(Rev.
), Requisition for Ordering Identification Supplies. Completed forms are to be mailed to the Identification Division, FBI, Washington, DC,

) Special Agents will obtain a Buccal DNA cheek swab from the arrestee they can be processed by the U.S. Marshals. The collected Buccal DNA DNA swab will be submitted to the FBI laboratory. The FBI laboratory is for ensuring the DNA profile is entered into the combined DNA Index (CODIS). The U.S. Marshals will only perform Buccal DNA cheek swab on their arrestees.
9.4.12.13.2 (08-11-2008) Fingerprinting Arrested Person

) Field Offices will be responsible for ordering Buccal DNA cheek swab kits directly from the FBI and ensuring all agents are trained in taking a cheek swab. Training and Buccal DNA cheek swab supplies can be obtained from FBI websites listed below: a. http://www.fbi.gov/hq/lab/html/instructions.htm (Buccal Kit Instructions) b. http://www.fbi.gov/hq/lab/html/kit_reorder_form_
htm (Buccal Kit Form) (

) A special agent who makes an arrest, whether with or without an arrest warrant, must take the arrested person, without unnecessary delay, before United nearest available US magistrate or other nearby officer empowered to persons charged with offenses against the laws of the United States. If the arrest was without an arrest warrant, a complaint must be filed (see Fed. R. Crim. P.
) Special agents must immediately inform their Supervisory Special Agent of any arrests they make. The SSA will, in turn, immediately report such Arrest mation to the ASAC/SAC. (

) When it is necessary to make an arrest prior to consulting the attorney for government, he/she shall be notified promptly of the arrest, advised fully of facts in the investigation, and requested to represent the government in the preliminary examination before the US magistrate. (

) If the arresting special agents believe valid reasons exist for opposing of the arrested person on personal bond, these reasons should be brought the attention of the attorney for the government prior to the bail hearing. attorney for the government may request that the special agent prepare a Reform Act Form No.
, AO–

, for use at the hearing. The form is at the Clerk’s Office for each US district court. The original will be furnished the attorney for the government and a duplicate will be retained in the gative file. (

) The above documents must be maintained electronically in the originating group’s administrative investigation file. While such documents will ideally kept in an electronic format, it is understood that paper documents may be more practical in some instances. Regardless of the format, these should be readily accessible for investigative purposes and properly retired (i.e., stored) with related investigation files when the investigation is closed. (

) In addition to the documents maintained in the group files, a copy of only Enforcement Action Review Form must be maintained in the SAC’s ″ ″ tive files. These centralized files may also be electronic, paper, or a combination thereof. However, they must be readily accessible indefinitely internal or external review. (

In addition, a current photograph of the fugitive should be submitted in format (jpg) to the *CI HQ-TECS mailbox. Director, Warrants and Forfeitures. This is to ensure that the person holding the warrant or commitment papers can be immediately notified of the detention. In those instances where the above officials are notified telephoni- cally, the notifying CI official will follow up with a written notification to them. The special agent participating in, verifying, or making the arrest will promptly update the Criminal Investigation Management Information System (CIMIS). The SAC, of the field office where the fugitive is wanted, shall follow up to ensure appropriate handling of the fugitive. Thereafter, he/she shall submit a brief report to the Director, Warrants and Forfeitures, detailing the action This report will also include a request to delete the TECS and NCIC entry. (Steps should also be taken to cancel any existing Wanted Circular with HQ USMC regarding the fugitive.) (

) When the SAC of the field office where the fugitive is wanted learns that the fugitive is located in another field office, he/she will immediately notify the of the other field office as to the location of the fugitive and will furnish all available information necessary for the apprehension of the fugitive. Where such notification is made by telephone with the request that the fugitive be arrested, confirmation should immediately follow by fax, so that the attorney for the government may have a documented request upon which to act. After the arrest has been made, the SAC shall submit a memorandum regarding cancellation in TECS to the Director, Warrants and Forfeitures (CI:OPS:WF), and notify the US Marshals Service to remove the fugitive from NCIC. Both of these actions must be documented in the investigative file. (

) A supplemental report shall be prepared by the special agent when an indi- vidual fails to surrender to the court on the date stipulated. The report should set forth the facts in the investigation and recommend (if appropriate) that proceedings be instituted charging the individual with a violation of
USC §
, Penalties for Failure to Appear. This action may materially aid CI to return, by extradition, individuals who have fled the country because a of
USC §
is usually an extraditable offense. (
) All entries into TECS will be made by HQ. The NCIC entries will be made by the local US Marshals Service. A written request must be received within

hours from the date of warrant, with a copy of the arrest warrant by the Director, Warrants and Forfeitures, and the local office of the US Marshals Service. One copy of the request is to be retained in the field office’s tive file. In urgent situations, the request memorandum and attachment may faxed or e-mailed to HQ and the US Marshals Service. The request dum can be accessed through Document Manager under the fugitive folder, requested from HQ. All entries into TECS will be made by HQ. The NCIC entries will be made by the local US Marshals Service. A written request must be received within 24 hours from the date of warrant, with a copy of the arrest warrant by the Director, Warrants and Forfeitures, and the local office of the US Marshals Service. One copy of the request is to be retained in the field office’s tive file. In urgent situations, the request memorandum and attachment may faxed or e-mailed to HQ and the US Marshals Service. The request dum can be accessed through Document Manager under the fugitive folder, requested from HQ. The request should contain the following to the extent available (these procedures should also be followed for requesting modifica- tions):

) If a decision is made to issue a wanted circular, the memorandum to the US Marshals Service must contain a request to do so, and include the following additional information: a. Fingerprints and fingerprint classification (if fingerprints are not readily available, any information that might help locate them will prove e.g, whether the fugitive was in the military service (indicate branch), employed by the Federal government, or employed by a contractor doing work for the government.) b. In lieu of fingerprints or fingerprint classification, clear photographs of the wanted person’s customary signature, or a sample of the wanted handwriting (in duplicate). c. The most clear and most recent photograph available of the subject. d. Any other information that might aid in the wanted person’s (

) Fugitive information in the TECS and NCIC are verified through a validation process, as required by Customs and FBI. Headquarters forwards validation forms that contain current information in TECS and NCIC to the field office to ensure the information is current and that the warrant is active. As part of this process, the field office must provide the contact person that was contacted verify that the warrant is active. After the validation form has been updated completed, it is reviewed and signed by a SSA or the ASAC/SAC. The signed form must be returned to the Director, CI:OPS:WF, before the validation form suspense date. Headquarters then audits the validation by contacting the vidual that was contacted by the field office to verify that contact was made and that the information provided was correct. ) A subject under sealed indictment may be entered into TECS with a fugitive status at the request of the SAC. (
) A subject under sealed indictment may be entered into NCIC at the of the US Marshals Service. (

) If a subject jumps bail, the original warrant is no longer valid and a bench warrant will be issued for failure to appear. A fugitive record will be input into NCIC by the US Marshals Service. The special agent must ensure the record is updated with the current status. Since TECS covers airports and borders, a TECS fugitive record to supplement the US Marshals’ NCIC record could increase the likelihood of capture. A memorandum with a copy the new failure to appear warrant should be submitted to the Director, CI:OPS:WF, requesting a TECS record entry. (
) In order to assist in the apprehension of fugitives, who were the subjects of investigations by CI, procedures are provided for the issuance of wanted circulars. (
) Requests for wanted circulars should be directed to the US Marshals (
) If a SAC wants to cancel a wanted circular created on a fugitive prior to January
, a memorandum requesting cancellation should be by the SAC, through the appropriate channels to the Director, CI:OPS:WF. wanted circulars created after January
, are the responsibility of the Marshals Service, and requests to cancel such circulars should be directed the local US Marshals Service office. (

) If it is believed that a fugitive has left the United States, a red notice may be issued by the International Criminal Police Organization (INTERPOL) to Fugitives in locating the fugitive. Such notices may also assist, depending on the law each INTERPOL member country, in having the fugitive detained so that US authorities may request extradition or other proceedings (e.g., expulsion, may lead to the fugitive’s return). A red notice may also be used when the fugitive is a national (including a dual national) of a country that does not extradite its citizens, if the fugitive has fled to that country but may later outside its borders. To request a red notice, contact the IRS-CI at the INTERPOL-US National Central Bureau (INTERPOL-USNCB) in ington, DC, at telephone (
, telefax (
) An INTERPOL red notice is an international wanted notice. It includes a tive’s photograph and fingerprints, and is ordinarily sent to all of Red Notice member countries (approximately

). Prior to forwarding an application for red notice, the following requirements must be met: a. The maximum penalty on the underlying offense is more than a year’s prisonment (or the fugitive is an escaped offender who has more than a year yet to serve). b. The indictment is not sealed. c. The Assistant US Attorney (AUSA) or other responsible prosecutor has agreed to extradite and has completed and signed a Prosecutor’s mation of Agreement to Extradite (Exhibit
). Forward this document to INTERPOL-USNCB with the application for red notice. (
) Internal Revenue Manual

If a subject jumps bail, the original warrant is no longer valid and a bench warrant will be issued for failure to appear. A fugitive record will be input into NCIC by the US Marshals Service. The special agent must ensure the TECS record is updated with the current status. Since TECS covers airports and land borders, a TECS fugitive record to supplement the US Marshals’ NCIC fugitive record could increase the likelihood of capture. A memorandum with a copy of the new failure to appear warrant should be submitted to the Director,

If it is believed that a fugitive has left the United States, a red notice may be issued by the International Criminal Police Organization (INTERPOL) to in locating the fugitive. Such notices may also assist, depending on the law each INTERPOL member country, in having the fugitive detained so that US authorities may request extradition or other proceedings (e.g., expulsion, that may lead to the fugitive’s return). A red notice may also be used when the fugitive is a national (including a dual national) of a country that does not extradite its citizens, if the fugitive has fled to that country but may later outside its borders. To request a red notice, contact the IRS-CI at the INTERPOL-US National Central Bureau (INTERPOL-USNCB) in

a. The maximum penalty on the underlying offense is more than a year’s im- prisonment (or the fugitive is an escaped offender who has more than a year yet to serve). b. The indictment is not sealed. c. The Assistant US Attorney (AUSA) or other responsible prosecutor has agreed to extradite and has completed and signed a Prosecutor’s Confir- mation of Agreement to Extradite (Exhibit
). Forward this document to INTERPOL-USNCB with the application for red notice.

Note: Send or telefax copies of the arrest warrant, indictment (or judgment of con- viction), NCIC entry, identity documents (or printouts of confirmations of identity document numbers) if available, and fugitive’s photograph and prints to the INTERPOL-USNCB with your red notice application. may be available from sources other than law enforcement. For instance, fugitives who have held fiduciary (including stockbroker) positions; have employed by the federal government or have served in the military; have been employed as teachers or in child care; or have been licensed for various professions may have been fingerprinted. Some states require or forefinger prints of drivers license applicants. (

) The INTERPOL-USNCB reviews each US application for a red notice and, upon approval, forwards it to the INTERPOL General Secetariat in Lyon, France. INTERPOL Lyon ensures that each red notice meets international legal requirements, then issues it in INTERPOL’s four official languages (Arabic, English, French, and Spanish) to all INTERPOL member countries, unless the requesting INTERPOL member excepts certain countries. Exhibit
, is a sample red notice form. Publication of a red notice may take to four months. (

) When the INTERPOL-USNCB forwards a red notice application to INTERPOL Lyon, the IRS US National Central Bureau (USNCB) representative will use INTERPOL’s dedicated telecommunications network to transmit the text of the red notice in the form of a fugitive location request also called a diffusion to INTERPOL members in any area of the world in which the fugitive may be found. In urgent cases, the INTERPOL-USNCB can transmit an INTERPOL fugitive location request even before receiving the red notice application. To request this, call the IRS-CI representative at the INTERPOL-USNCB, (
-hour number). (
) The USNCB sends a courtesy copy of every fugitive location request to the Fugitive Unit, Office of International Affairs, Criminal Division, US Department of Justice, telephone (

The Office of International Affairs handles all international extraditions involving the United States. When a fugitive from US justice is located abroad, the prosecutor must, therefore, contact the Office of International Affairs, telephone (
, telefax (
, to make a request for the fugitive’s provisional arrest in that country with a view toward extradition to the United States. (
) The Office of International Affairs, US Department of Justice, also has a Duty Attorney available
-hours a day through the Department of Justice, Command Center telephone (
, to assist with the request for visional arrest with a view toward extradition of a fugitive located abroad at night or on a weekend. (

) Some foreign countries can use an INTERPOL fugitive location request to detain a fugitive for a brief period under their domestic law (e.g., because the fugitive failed to disclose a criminal record or is otherwise an undesirable alien). Some foreign countries can also use an INTERPOL red notice as the equivalent of a request, pursuant to the applicable extradition treaty, for provi- sional arrest with a view toward extradition. As the USNCB electronically transmits the fugitive location request directly to other INTERPOL member countries, the US prosecutor must, therefore, be prepared immediately to through the Office of International Affairs, US Department of Justice, to Internal Revenue Manual Cat. , for complete red notice information and assistance. The representative can whether a red notice is appropriate and, if so, forward the most current infor- mation and forms necessary for red notice application. (

) If the fugitive’s location abroad is known, and if the country in question can extradite the fugitive, an INTERPOL fugitive location request or red notice not be needed. In such cases, the prosecutor should work directly with an attorney at the Office of International Affairs, US Department of Justice, (
, fax (

, Washington, DC,
, who handles extradition from the country in question. (

) A request for provisional arrest with a view toward extradition is in many the first step in requesting the extradition to the United States of an interna- tional fugitive. A provisional arrest request contains substantially the same information as an INTERPOL fugitive location request or an INTERPOL red notice, but is a separate document sent to a specific country with which the United States has an extradition treaty. The Office of International Affairs in Criminal Division, US Department of Justice, which handles all international extraditions involving the United States, transmits the provisional arrest through the US Department of State unless the applicable treaty recognizes INTERPOL or another channel as an official channel for that purpose. In cases, the Office of International Affairs may also send a courtesy copy of the provisional arrest request via INTERPOL. (

) The contents of the extradition request itself depend upon the applicable An extradition request generally includes: a. a prosecutor’s affidavit describing the US proceeding b. a special agent’s affidavit about the facts of the investigation c. witness statements d. certified copies of the arrest warrant, indictment, or judgment of e. the fugitive’s photograph f. the fugitive’s fingerprints (

), to contact the US prosecutor and to prepare a provisional arrest request at any time for any US red notice fugitive located in a foreign country that can extradite. ) It is essential to cancel an INTERPOL request for fugitive location (also as a diffusion) or INTERPOL red notice if: a. the fugitive has been apprehended in (or extradited or otherwise to) the United States b. when the NCIC entry is cancelled c. when the charges against the fugitive are dropped d. when, for any reason, the prosecutor declines to prosecute the fugitive e. when the prosecutor is no longer willing (for any reason) to extradite nationally (
) A reason not to prosecute may be that essential witnesses and/or evidence no longer available. (

) Timely cancellation of the INTERPOL request for fugitive location (diffusion) red notice may prevent the detention abroad, on behalf of the United States, of: a. A person whom the US prosecutor is no longer able or willing to prosecute. b. Any person who is not a fugitive from US justice but whose name, date birth, and additional identifying information may closely resemble those the fugitive who is the subject of an INTERPOL request for fugitive location or red notice. 9.4.12-3 (12-10-2001) Statement to Arrested or Detained Foreign Nationals
Suggested Statements to Arrested or Detained Foreign Natione's
When Consular Notification is at the Foreign National's Option

As a non-U.S. citizen who is being arrested or detained, you are entitled to haveus notify your country’s consular representatives here in the United States. Aconsular official from your country may be able to help you obtain legal counsel,and may contact your family and visit you in detention, among other things. If youwant us to notify your country’s consular officials, you can request this notificationnow, or at any time in the future. After your consular officials are notified, theymay call or visit you. Do you want us to notify your country’s consular officials?
Statement 2:
When Consular Notification is Mandatory

Because of your nationality, we are required to notify your country's consularrepresentative here in the United States that you have been arrested or detained.After your consular officials are notified, they may call or visit you. You are notrequired to accept their assistance, but they may be able to help you obtain legalcounsel and may contact your family and visit you in detention, among otherthings. We will be notifying your country's consular officials as soon as possible.

In consideration of transmission by INTERPOL -- US National Central Bureau (USNCB) of an INTERPOL request for fugitive location (diffusion) or red notice (International Wanted Notice) for UN- DERSCORE , F/N UNDERSCORE , (DOB UNDERSCORE , POB UNDERSCORE ) via dedicated, world-wide telecommunications system, and

1. That the US Department of Justice, Office of International Affairs (OIA), (202) 514-0000, after hours OIA Duty Attorney (202) 514-5000 (DOJ 24-hour Command Center); telefax (202) 514-0080 shall diately transmit a request for the fugitive’s provisional arrest with a view toward extradition, or for the fugitive’s return to the United States by other legal means.

2. To submit a draft request for the fugitive’s extradition to OIA within 10 days of the fugitive’s provi- sional arrest or as agreed with the responsible OIA attorney (extradition request normally includes prosecutor’s and agent’s affidavits; certified copies of charging document(s) (or judgment of conviction) and arrest warrant(s); witness statement(s); fugitive’s photograph and fingerprints.)

3. To pay all costs of extradition (translation of extradition request if necessary, round-trip air fare and per diem for two US Marshals or one Marshal and one state/local official; fugitive’s one-way air fare; foreign attorney fees if applicable).
4. To inform the USNCB and OIA immediately in writing:

INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE - CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONRISK ASSESSMENT GUIDE

This is a guide for assessing the potentiai risk in any enforcement operation. It shouid be prepared by the assigned specialagent, reviewad by the Supervisary Special Agent, and approved by the Assistant Special Agent in Charge and/ior SpecialAgent in Charge. Each of the considerations should be commented on in the column provided, with the level of risk (iow,medium, or high) entered in the last column. General criteria for evaluating high, medium, and low risk are identified below:
High Risk

High risk situations are those in which it is probable that the risk factor/enforcement action could result in death or seriousphysical injury to the agent or others. Cl agents are not trained to handle high risk enforcement actions. Amongcircumstances that would create a high risk situation are the following:
Presence of booby trap
resence of a barricaded or fortified locatio
eed for tear ga
eed for explosive breachin
oxic/Hazardous environmen
resence of sophisticated weaponr
vidence of premeditated acts of violence against law enforcement officers, combined with the known ability of occupantsto offer armed resistance to entering agent
rior histary of violent criminat behavior, combined with the known ability of occupants to offer armed resistance to enteri
gent
ny set of facts which lead the special agent to believe that there is a likelihood of serious physical injury or death unlessspecialized procedures or equipment are used in the entry.

If a determination is made that entry into a premises or structure presents a high risk situation, special agents will not engagein the entry. Other means, such as use of specially trained entry teams from other local, state or federal agencies, will beconsidered. Once entry is made and a location is secured, special agents will be able to enter to compiete the search.
Medium Risk

Medium risk situations are those in which it is possibie that the risk factor/enforcement action could result in a non-permanentphysical injury to the agent or others. Agents have the requisite training to deal with these situations and, as such, areauthorized to make entry. An example of a medium risk situation is the presence of a firearm, absent other knowledge of intentor criminai history, at a location.
Low Risk
Low risk situations are those in which it is unlikely that the risk factor/enforcement action could result in a non-permanenphysical injury to the agent or others.
